arm_group.description: 60 minutes of high intensity treadmill running

brief_summary.textblock:
The primary aim of this study was to determine the effects of an acute bout of high
      intensity exercise on the brains response to viewing pictures of food using functional
      magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Intense Exercise on Neural Responses to Food.

detailed_description.textblock:
It is clear that intense exercise impacts on peripheral appetite regulation, however very
      little is known about the impact of high-intensity exercise on central appetite regulation.
      This study aimed to investigate the effects of high-intensity exercise on both central and
      peripheral responses to images of food. Functional magnetic resonance techniques were used
      to assess the brains response to images of high and low calorie foods, following a short
      bout of high-intensity exercise. Appetite hormone concentrations were also measured. It was
      hypothesized that, due to the known effects of high-intensity exercise on appetite
      regulatory hormones and subjective appetite ratings, the activation of reward-related brain
      regions to visual food cues would be modulated following intense physical activity.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy, non-smokers, free from cardiovascular disease and metabolic disease, no
             medication, participated in moderate/vigorous physical activity (>2 hours per week)

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Smokers, history of cardiovascular/metabolic disease, low physical activity levels,
             inability to participate in fMRI scanning sessions including contraindications to MRI

clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of High Intensity Exercise on Neural Responses to Images of Food

primary_outcome.description: Volunteers completed an fMRI assessment following 60 minutes of intense exercise and 60 minutes of rest on two separate occasions.
primary_outcome.measure: Neural responses following exercise and rest

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Blood samples were taken using a cannula system for both trials. Concentrations of appetite regulating hormones were measured from plasma.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Blood samples taken at baseline, following exercise/rest, prior to the fMRI assessment and immediately following the fMRI assessment

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Basic Science
